mw_today: Sunny, with a high near 45. Light and variable wind becoming southwest 5 to 10 mph in the afternoon.
mw_tonight: Mostly clear, with a low around 23. Southwest wind 5 to 10 mph becoming light and variable  after midnight.
btac_hazard:
The Tetons picked up maybe 1-3 inches of snow yesterday, mostly in convective cells around midday. Good freeze last night, and not much in the way of wind. Today will be the first majorly sunny day since that nice pulse of snow on Thursday, so things will come a bit unglued in places. Looks like temps will reach the freezing point on the peaks. High pressure is on deck for tomorrow as well. Now the extended outlook is pretty unsettled for the rest of April. It's fun to watch this change on a daily basis and a good reminder that predicting the future is a silly business. 

The last wave of high pressure put a pretty solid cap on the seasons snowpack. It will be interesting to see what happens over the course of the next two days as we heat back up. The pack at the middle and upper elevations is still pretty far away from "isothermal".  Recent avalanche activity has mostly been confined to some wet loose, dry loose, and maybe a rogue wind slab or two.
btac_weatherdisc:
Yesterday: Mostly cloudy with some convective snow showers, especially around midday. 1-3 inches of snow popped up in certain locations (seems like Victor got the most). 

Last Night: Mostly clear early, then transitioned to partly cloudy. No new snow overnight. Low temperatures are currently in the low 20s in the valleys and near 10 degrees on the peaks. Winds averaged 10 mph out of the West on Rendezvous Summit. Seems like a nice little layer of surface hoar got laid down around 8k'. 

Today's Forecast: HIGH PRESSURE! Mostly sunny with temperatures near freezing on the peaks and in the low 40s in the valleys. Winds will be westerly in the 5-15 mph range on the ridgelines.
btac_bottomline: The avalanche danger will start off at LOW this morning then transition to MODERATE as the snowpack heats up. Small wind slabs remain a possible threat in the alpine, and wet loose activity will be more pronounced on southerly aspects. Monitor the effects of the sun today and seek out dry unconsolidated snow that has not been stiffened by the wind. Minimize exposure time on steep sunlit slopes, especially in and around rocky outcroppings.
legecast: 4.10.23 - We are now closed for the winter season. Thanks for an incredible, record breaking season! See you May 20 when the tram re-opens for the summer. Bike Park and other activities and lifts opens June 12.

Happy Saturday! Enjoy some sunny skies today with highs in the upper 30's and steady, low winds throughout the day. Get out and enjoy closing weekend with us!
Sierra_weatherdisc: Sunny and warmer temperatures are expected through this weekend with highs in the mid 40's to mid 50's above 7000'.  Temperature inversions were in place overnight with colder air down in the lower elevation valleys and warmer near freezing temperatures along the Sierra Crest.  These temperature inversions are expected to further increase tonight.  Light to moderate SW winds will pick up this afternoon.  Sunday is expected to continue to be sunny and warm with increasing winds in the afternoon ahead of a developing storm starting on Monday.
Sierra_btmline: Warmer temperatures and strong April sunshine will make wet loose avalanches possible as rapid warming occurs today.  Large cornices along ridgelines will also weaken due to the increased warming temperatures.  The window for supportable snow conditions will be shorter than yesterday-move away from avalanche terrain as the snow surface becomes deep and unsupportable.
Sierra_hazard_disc:
• Some glide cracks have formed on steep slopes in rocky areas. Like cornice fall events, the exact timing of glide crack avalanches are notoriously difficult to predict. Due to the uncertainty, consider avoiding travel on or below slopes with glide cracks.
  • Over this weekend, the surface crust formed during overnight refreeze is expected to become thinner each night and melt faster each day due to increasingly warmer daytime and nighttime air temperatures. The window of time for travel in avalanche terrain before wet snow avalanche problems become a concern will get shorter each day. For travel in avalanche terrain, plan to start early and end early.
UT_btmline: The avalanche danger is MODERATE on slopes facing east, south, and west at all elevations for wet snow avalanches. Both natural and human-triggered avalanches will be possible during the day's heat once the snow becomes wet and unstable.Other slopes facing the north side of the compass will not heat up as much, and therefore you will find a LOW avalanche danger.  Slide-for-life conditions (where you cannot arrest after falling) are possible on smooth, hard, and frozen snow surfaces.
UT_avyconditions: Under clear skies, the current mountain temperatures range from 22-32 °F allowing for another solid refreeze of the snowpack. Winds blow southwest at speeds of 10-15 mph. High pressure, sunshine, and increasing southerly winds are on tap for today. This morning we will warm much quicker as the temperatures are about 10 degrees warmer than yesterday at this time. Mountain temperatures will climb into the mid-40s and low 50s °F this afternoon, and winds will increase out of the southwest and blow 10-15 mph, gusting into the 20s.   The sun warmed the snow surface yesterday, allowing many riders to enjoy smooth turns on many aspects and elevations. Some even found 1-3 inches of dry powder snow in the upper alpine. Today will be no different, except it might get too hot and mushy in the afternoon eliminating the "its corn" song party on Instagram's story and reels.

solitude_detail: Spring skiing will be in full effect today with all-day sunshine and temperatures ranging from the mid-30s to mid-40s. Temperatures were below freezing last night, so expect some early-day crunch as the mountain warms up. Groomed runs should provide the best skiing and riding through the morning – Sunshine Bowl and Main Street are great places to be when the snow starts to soften. Yesterday we opened all our terrain except Fantasy Ridge and expect the same terrain open again today. For advanced skiers, our gated terrain has been offering both frozen ugh and corn snow bliss. Highway to Heaven and the far reaches of east-facing Honeycomb were skiing great around noon yesterday. Wherever you end up on the mountain, you’re going to love the spring vibe at Solitude right now.
